Guy and Schroeder both identify Haggard's novels Allan Quatermain and Maiwa's Revenge as the alluded to works containing footnotes. While Guy notes that footnotes contain "information. . .derived from Haggard's own inexperience of Africa," which would suggest the jab at their inclusion being to sere as "cowardly corroboration," Schroeder argues that many of the footnotes in Maiwa's Revenge are "mock-serious," and that "Wilde must have enjoyed [them] and. . .is here criticizing tongue-and-cheek" (Guy 367, Schroeder 29).
